Literature Review: The p-arms of human acrocentric chromosomes, specifically chromosomes 13, 14, 15, 21, and 22, have long been recognized for their unique structural and functional characteristics, primarily due to the presence of nucleolar organizer regions (NORs). These regions are critical for the biogenesis of ribosomes, housing the ribosomal DNA (rDNA) genes that are transcribed into precursor ribosomal RNA (pre-rRNA). The organization and transcription of rDNA repeats in a telomere-to-centromere direction underscore the specialized role of these chromosomal segments in cellular function and development (McStay, 2016). Recent advancements in long-read sequencing technologies have facilitated the assembly of full DNA sequences for acrocentric p-arms, revealing their complexity and variability in size, ranging from 10.1 to 16.7 Mb, which accounts for approximately 2.2% of the human genome (Miga et al., 2020). This has opened new avenues for understanding the genomic architecture and functional implications of these regions. The NORs are flanked by distal and proximal junctions, with distal junctions showing evidence of functionality, suggesting a role in the regulation of rDNA transcription and nucleolar organization (Floutsakou et al., 2013). Beyond the rDNA arrays, the p-arms are composed of various satellite DNA classes and segmental duplications. These elements are not merely structural but play a significant role in facilitating recombination events between heterologous chromosomes. Such recombination is implicated in the formation of Robertsonian translocations, a common type of chromosomal rearrangement in humans that can lead to genetic disorders (Bandelt et al., 2010). The study of acrocentric p-arms has also shed light on the dynamic nature of the nucleolus, which is the physical manifestation of rDNA transcription and ribosome assembly. The nucleolus is not a static entity but undergoes changes in size and number in response to cellular demands, reflecting the transcriptional activity of the NORs (Boisvert et al., 2007). Furthermore, the heterochromatic nature of the p-arms, characterized by the presence of repetitive sequences and low gene density, contrasts with the euchromatic regions of the genome. This heterochromatin is essential for maintaining the structural integrity of chromosomes and regulating gene expression through epigenetic mechanisms (Grewal & Jia, 2007). The exploration of the NOR chromosomal context has revealed its importance in the spatial organization of the genome within the nucleus, influencing gene expression patterns and chromosomal interactions (Nemeth & Langst, 2011). Additionally, the study of acrocentric p-arms has implications for understanding human evolution and genetic diversity. The variation in the number and organization of rDNA repeats among individuals and populations reflects the dynamic nature of these genomic regions and their potential role in adaptation (Stults et al., 2008). In conclusion, the p-arms of human acrocentric chromosomes represent a fascinating area of research that bridges the fields of genetics, molecular biology, and evolutionary biology. The ongoing exploration of these regions, fueled by technological advancements and interdisciplinary approaches, continues to unravel the complex rules that govern their structure, function, and evolution.
